Anybody got any idea how to handle pure liquids
in CANTERA?  I've created my own CTI file for liquid
water (hacked, in part from the nasa.cti file).
However, when trying to import it into MATLAB using:

   liquid_h2o=solution('liquid_h2o.cti', 'liquid_water')

where 'liquid_h2o.cti' is the CTI file and 'liquid_water'
is the identifier for the sole liquid defined in the file.
The python code fails when it encounters the keyword
'pure_liquid' (note that in the documentation it states
than this should be 'stoichiometric_liquid' - however
Prof. Goodwin says that the doc is ahead of the s/w
in this respect and that 'pure_liquid' should be used).

What is interesting is that I have performed a search
in the CANTERA distribution (inclding the CANTERA binaries,
MATLAB toolbox, and Python CANTERA site files) and cannot
find any instance of the string 'pure_liquid'
(the string 'stoichiometric_liquid' appears only in the
doc and nowhere in the code either).

Specifically, I've also scanned through the ctml_writer.py
Python file and could not find a class for 'pure_liquid'.
However, I could find 'pure_solid'.

Am I doing some thing very wring here?

The MATLAB command and the resulting error trace
is below:

>> solution('liquid_h2o.cti', 'liquid_h2o')
Traceback (most recent call last): 
  File "./.cttmp.py", line 8, in ? 
    execfile(file) 
  File "D:\Applications\Common Files/Cantera/data/liquid_h2o.cti",
line 1, in ? 
    pure_liquid( name = "liquid_h2o", 
NameError: name 'pure_liquid' is not defined 
 
??? 
Procedure: ct2ctml
Error:   could not convert input file to CTML
 command line was: python ./.cttmp.py>> ct2ctml.log 2>&1
Check error messages above for syntax errors.

Error in ==>
d:\applications\cantera15\toolbox\cantera\cantera\ctmethods.dll
Error in ==>
d:\applications\cantera15\toolbox\cantera\cantera\@XML_Node\XML_Node.m
On line 10  ==>    x.id = ctmethods(10,15,0,src); % newxml(name)

Error in ==>
d:\applications\cantera15\toolbox\cantera\cantera\@Solution\Solution.m
On line 30  ==> doc = XML_Node('doc',src);

Thanks for your patience in reading this posting!
